title: Experiencing various database exceptions with Rails 7.1  · Issue #796 · bensheldon/good_job

last_post.content:
ok! let's look at some deadlocks.

I'm working through this issue: https://github.com/bensheldon/good_job/issues/796

The deadlocks are coming from a deadlock hotspot in GoodJob: The Notifier.

The Notifier is responsible for both pg LISTEN, and registering/clearing a Process record (it uses a long-lived Advisory Lock). The Notifier uses a long-running thread and a dedicated database connection. So lots of dragons here!

title: Add `tootctl accounts migrate` by ClearlyClaire · Pull Request #22330 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
I think (thanks to a mastodon instance admin for looking at their logs!) that what happened is that my instance got slow, so some of the HTTP requests to my server timed out and failed. I think 3 possible fixes are:

1. wait 30 days & rerun the migration myself
2. ask my old instance to retry the migration, once it's running a release with this code https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/22330
3. instance admins can maybe manually retry failed jobs (seems like a lot to ask though)

h/t @nova for her work on this

last_post.content:
@mnl I can totally relate to this having been burnt by ORMs in the past.

I'm a big fan of just generating static types for my database with https://github.com/rmp135/sql-ts and then using those generated types to add some loose type-safety to my sql queries.

For example: typing the result sets or referencing table/column names through an enum.

Other options for small-ish JS libraries I looked into:
- https://alpinejs.dev/: the major player in this space
- https://htmx.org/: also well-loved, but solves a slightly different use-case
- https://github.com/vuejs/petite-vue

More details about each and some other lesser-known options at: https://unsuckjs.com/.

I would like to thank @akib for the amazing Emacs package EAT, or Emulate A Terminal [1].

This has taken my eshell and tramp usage to the next level.

title: fix: sanitize HTML from Mastodon servers by jviide · Pull Request #788 · elk-zone/elk

last_post.content:
Elk, the Mastodon client built in the open, looks and feels great. Check it out at @elk.

It's so nice I also want to use it. So I recently took a look at the code and opened some pull requests dealing fixing some security issues:

Sanitize HTML from Mastodon servers: https://github.com/elk-zone/elk/pull/788
Prevent HTML injections to code blocks: https://github.com/elk-zone/elk/pull/1165

Thanks to the crew (@antfu, @daniel, @sxzz, @patak et al.) for being super responsive and encouraging. They've dealt with the issues in an exemplary way, and gotten the patches out really fast.

Some technical background: The Mastodon API returns the post contents (among other things) as raw HTML. The default Mastodon server implementation does sanitize the HTML. But sometimes server-side sanitation lets things slip through, or the server itself could be in malicious hands.

If the client accepts the incoming raw HTML as-is, it can lead to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities. Let's say a server returns a post with HTML content like <script>...</script>. If the client just trusts the server and injects that content to the page, the server can effectively execute arbitrary code in the client context - for example to steal the client's login information. Or to take over the whole page like in the attached demo video 🙂

Therefore, it's best to also sanitize the HTML on the client side. This can be tricky. Doubly so if the client wants implement features like rendering source code blocks with syntax highlighting, or turning Twitter mentions into links.

The linked pull requests fortify a couple of places where Elk prepares HTML content for display. I sincerely hope other people in the infosec scene find Elk's UI intriguing, maybe enough to even take a look at the code. It's a great chance to make a cool up-and-coming tool better!

#elk #vuejs #vue #xss

Did you know the #CSSWG extended the :nth-of-type/:nth-child selectors to be much more powerful?

Safari shipped support for these new superpowers in 2015! https://caniuse.com/css-nth-child-of

But none of the other browsers did… so you probably haven’t heard about it.

Then Apple proposed :nth-* pseudo-classes interoperability for Interop 2023: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/225
